newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan to cut import tariffs to 6.0 pct from 8.64.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan to cut import tariffs to 6.0 pct from 8.64.

text.p: Taiwan plans to cut average nominal import tarriffs to 6.0 percent by the year 2010 from 8.64 percent now, a Finance Ministry official said on Tuesday.

The move, which would be part of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum's trade liberalisation, would be executed step by step to follow "the APEC trade liberalisation," the official said by telephone.
By the year 2000, the ministry plans to cut nominal tariffs to an average of 7.9 percent, with 50 percent of Taiwan's imported goods having a tariff below 5.0 percent.
Currently only 40 percent of imported goods have a tariff under 5.0 percent, the official said.
By 2005, the average tariff will be further lowered to 6.3 percent, with 60 percent of the goods having a tarriff below 5.0 percent, he said.
By 2010, the average tariff will be cut to 6.0 percent, and 65 percent of the goods will have a tariff below 5.0 percent.
